thread.title: Tuolumne County Museum plans harvest festival
thread.title_full: Tuolumne County Museum plans harvest festival

title: Tuolumne County Museum plans harvest festival
text:
Tuolumne County Museum plans harvest festival Tuolumne County Museum plans harvest festival By Lacey Peterson, The Union Democrat October 01, 2015 10:35 pm Gold pans decorated by Tuolumne County residents, including the one above by Native Daughters of the Golden West Golden Era Parlor No. 99 of Columbia, will be on display Saturday. Lacey Peterson / Union Democrat, copyright 2015 The Tuolumne County History Center and Museum will host a free family and history oriented harvest festival Oct. 10. 
The event will be held from 1 to 5 p.m. in the Tuolumne County Museum courtyard at 158 Bradford St. in Sonora. 
The festival will feature a display of gold pans from the museum’s 2015 Panning for History countywide gold pan art contest. At 3 p.m., there will be an award’s ceremony for the contest winners in various categories. About 200 people, children and adults, participated in the contest. 
The event will include Gold Rush-era games, including Hardluck Lin’s “shut the box” game, jacks, and bubbles on a string, said Sarge Furman, from the museum’s board of governors. 
There will also be showings of the Tuolumne County Historical Society’s 30-minute film on Tuolumne County’s filmmaking heyday. There also will be lessons on how to pan for gold. 
Alice Kraus, an expert in mid-1800s quilts, will bring her collection of quilts to display. 
Fran Azevedo Gardner, who grew up in Tuttletown, will bring her father’s childhood wagon to display. Her dad, Joe Azevedo, was the first president of the Tuolumne County Historical Society. 
There will be photo opportunities at each exhibit, and people can have their pictures put on a poster, Furman said. 
At 2 p.m., Sonora City Historian Pat Perry will give a tour of the Jewish Cemetery near the museum. 
There will also be lemonade and cookies. 
“There should be something for everybody,” Furman said. 
For more information, call the History Center at 532-4227. Follow UnionDemocrat.com
